sn12.45:1: Thus have I heard. On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Ñātika in the Brick Hall. Then, while the Blessed One was alone in seclusion, he uttered this Dhamma exposition:[n.25]Dhammapariyāya,a method of presenting the teaching. This sutta recurs atSN35.3, where it is called Upassuti, "Listening In." On Ñātika, see V, n.330.
sn12.45:2: "In dependence on the eye and forms, eye-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact. With contact as condition, feelingcomes to be; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging … . Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
sn12.45:3: "In dependence on the ear and sounds … In dependence on the mind and mental phenomena, mind-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact. With contact as condition, feelingcomes to be; with feeling as condition, craving; with craving as condition, clinging … . Such is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
sn12.45:4: "In dependence on the eye and forms, eye-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact. With contact as condition, feelingcomes to be; with feeling as condition, craving. But with the remainderless fading away and cessation of that same craving comes cessation of clinging; with the cessation of clinging, cessation of existence … . Such is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering.sn.ii.75
sn12.45:5: "In dependence on the ear and sounds … In dependence on the mind and mental phenomena, mind-consciousness arises. The meeting of the three is contact. With contact as condition, feelingcomes to be; with feeling as condition, craving. But with the remainderless fading away and cessation of that same craving comes cessation of clinging; with the cessation of clinging, cessation of existence … . Such is the cessation of this whole mass of suffering."
sn12.45:6: Now on that occasion a certain bhikkhu was standing listening in on the Blessed One. The Blessed One saw him standing there listening in and said to him: "Did you hear that Dhamma exposition, bhikkhu?"
